claim:
Consider the following background information: Thirty minutes after delivery, a 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) newborn has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks" gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother has noticed the bluish lip discoloration worsen when she fed and improve when she cried. The patient"s pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. The crying infant"s lungs are clear to auscultation.

Given the background information the following is corrrect: Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show the presence of a scaphoid abdomen.

supporting.text: A scaphoid abdomen is a classic sign of congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which can present with respiratory distress and cyanosis in newborns.

attacks.text: A scaphoid abdomen is a classic sign of congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which can present with respiratory distress and cyanosis in newborns.

Clear lung auscultation does not rule out congenital diaphragmatic hernia, as bowel sounds may not always be present or detectable early.
The worsening cyanosis during feeding and improvement with crying is more consistent with a cardiac or pulmonary vascular anomaly than a diaphragmatic hernia.
Congenital diaphragmatic hernia can also cause variable cyanosis due to shifting of mediastinal contents during feeding or crying.
